Line 33: Line 33:
* {{flag|Israel}} â President [[Shimon Peres]] said Mubarak's "contribution to peace will never be forgotten. I thank him for saving many people's lives by preventing war. The biggest problem isn't changing the government but changing the face of a country as poor as Egypt." He added concerns about the Muslim Brotherhood: "Elections in Egypt are dangerous. Should the Muslim Brotherhood be elected they will not bring peace. Democracy without peace is not a democracy. We fear there will be a change in government without a change in the circumstances which led to this state."<ref>Efraim, Omri (5 February 2011). [http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4024283,00.html "Peres Praises Mubarak for His Contribution to Peace â In Jerusalem Conference President thanks His Egyptian Counterpart for 'Saving Many People's Lives by Preventing War'; Expresses Concern over Possibility of Muslim Brotherhood's Rise to Power"]. ''[[Ynetnews]]''. Retrieved 6 February 2011.</ref>
* {{flag|Israel}} â President [[Shimon Peres]] said Mubarak's "contribution to peace will never be forgotten. I thank him for saving many people's lives by preventing war. The biggest problem isn't changing the government but changing the face of a country as poor as Egypt." He added concerns about the Muslim Brotherhood: "Elections in Egypt are dangerous. Should the Muslim Brotherhood be elected they will not bring peace. Democracy without peace is not a democracy. We fear there will be a change in government without a change in the circumstances which led to this state."<ref>Efraim, Omri (5 February 2011). [http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4024283,00.html "Peres Praises Mubarak for His Contribution to Peace â In Jerusalem Conference President thanks His Egyptian Counterpart for 'Saving Many People's Lives by Preventing War'; Expresses Concern over Possibility of Muslim Brotherhood's Rise to Power"]. ''[[Ynetnews]]''. Retrieved 6 February 2011.</ref>
*: [[Prime Minister of Israel|Israeli Prime Minister]] [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] and the Israeli Foreign Ministry announced on 28 January that they are keeping a close track of the situation in neighbouring Egypt, but are refraining from taking a political stance. Ministers were told to refrain from commenting<ref name="time">Vick, Karl (30 January 2011). [http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2045166,00.html "As Egypt's Crisis Grows, So Do the Anxieties in Israel"]. ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''. Retrieved 2 February 2011.</ref> due to the sensitive nature of [[Egypt-Israel relations|relations]].
*: [[Prime Minister of Israel|Israeli Prime Minister]] [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] and the Israeli Foreign Ministry announced on 28 January that they are keeping a close track of the situation in neighbouring Egypt, but are refraining from taking a political stance. Ministers were told to refrain from commenting<ref name="time">Vick, Karl (30 January 2011). [http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2045166,00.html "As Egypt's Crisis Grows, So Do the Anxieties in Israel"]. ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''. Retrieved 2 February 2011.</ref> due to the sensitive nature of [[Egypt-Israel relations|relations]].
â
*: Foreign Minister [[Avigdor Lieberman]] told European diplomats at the [[Knesset]] that the root cause of the unrest was internal problems. "Whoever thinks that the Palestinian-Israeli conflict is part of the problems in the Middle East is trying to escape reality. [The] big picture of the Middle East shows that major points of contention stem from challenges and confrontations within Islamic society. The Arab world is becoming increasingly weakened. At the end of the day, it is clear to everyone, even to the [[Palestinian Authority]], that the greatest danger they are facing is not Zionism, but rather Hamas and Jihad."<ref>{{cite web|last=Lis |first=Jonathan |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/lieberman-mideast-uprisings-show-the-arab-world-is-weakening-1.341859 |title=Lieberman: Mideast uprisings show the Arab world is weakening â Haaretz Daily Newspaper | Israel News |publisher=Haaretz.com |date=7 November 2010 |accessdate=11 February 2011}}</ref> During the early days of the protests, the Foreign Ministry was receiving updates every few hours and Lieberman was in close contact with the Israeli ambassador to Egypt, Yitzhak Levanon.<ref>{{cite web|author=Ravid, Barak (with news agencies)|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/pm-netanyahu-israel-will-monitor-but-not-comment-on-egypt-protests-1.339895 |title=PM Netanyahu: Israel Will Monitor But Not Comment on Egypt Protests â The Foreign Ministry Is Conducting Status Updates on Egypt Every Couple of Hours and Foreign Minister Avigdor Lieberman Has Been Maintaining Close Contact with Israel's Ambassador to Egypt|work=[[Haaretz]] |date=29 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> The Ministry was concerned over "substantial" changes in the regime.<ref name="israel evacuation">{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.qassam.ps/news-4112-Israel_expresses_concern_as_protesters_continued.html |title=Israel Expresses Concern as Protesters Continued |publisher=[[Izz ad-Din al-Qassam Brigades]] |date=30 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> The [[Associated Press]] reported that security officials anonymously expressed concern that the violence could threaten ties with Egypt, and spread to the [[Palestinian Authority]].<ref>{{cite news |author=[[Staff writer]]|title=Israel Watches Egypt Uprising with Fear |url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5g7bZEz0wOwtiHUPRpYY1NTG2YQVQ?docId=b2b9acdbd23144e1a56fa248589c402c |publisher=[[Associated Press]] (via [[Google News]])|date=29 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> The government was said to be pressuring the US to postpone a plan for Mubarak's departure so that it could prepare for any likely outcome.<ref name="bloombergreactions"/>
+
*: Foreign Minister [[Avigdor Lieberman]] told European diplomats at the [[Knesset]] that the root cause of the unrest was internal problems. "Whoever thinks that the Palestinian-Israeli conflict is part of the problems in the Middle East is trying to escape reality. [The] big picture of the Middle East shows that major points of contention stem from challenges and confrontations within Islamic society. The Arab world is becoming increasingly weakened. At the end of the day, it is clear to everyone, even to the [[Palestinian Authority]], that the greatest danger they are facing is not Zionism, but rather Hamas and Jihad."<ref>{{cite web|last=Lis |first=Jonathan |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/lieberman-mideast-uprisings-show-the-arab-world-is-weakening-1.341859 |title=Lieberman: Mideast uprisings show the Arab world is weakening â Haaretz Daily Newspaper | Israel News |publisher=Haaretz.com |date=7 November 2010 |accessdate=11 February 2011}}</ref> During the early days of the protests, the Foreign Ministry was receiving updates every few hours and Lieberman was in close contact with the Israeli ambassador to Egypt, Yitzhak Levanon.<ref>{{cite web|author=Ravid, Barak (with news agencies)|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/pm-netanyahu-israel-will-monitor-but-not-comment-on-egypt-protests-1.339895 |title=PM Netanyahu: Israel Will Monitor But Not Comment on Egypt Protests â The Foreign Ministry Is Conducting Status Updates on Egypt Every Couple of Hours and Foreign Minister Avigdor Lieberman Has Been Maintaining Close Contact with Israel's Ambassador to Egypt|work=[[Haaretz]] |date=29 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> The Ministry was concerned over "substantial" changes in the regime.<ref name="israel evacuation">{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.qassam.ps/news-4112-Israel_expresses_concern_as_protesters_continued.html |title=Israel Expresses Concern as Protesters Continued |publisher=[[Izz ad-Din al-Qassam Brigades]] |date=30 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> The [[Associated Press]] reported that security officials anonymously expressed concern that the violence could threaten ties with Egypt, and spread to the [[Palestinian Authority]].<ref>{{cite news |author=[[Staff writer]]|title=Israel Watches Egypt Uprising with Fear |url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5g7bZEz0wOwtiHUPRpYY1NTG2YQVQ?docId=b2b9acdbd23144e1a56fa248589c402c |publisher=Associated Press (via [[Google News]])|date=29 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> The government was said to be pressuring the US to postpone a plan for Mubarak's departure so that it could prepare for any likely outcome.<ref name="bloombergreactions"/>
** [[Binyamin Ben-Eliezer]], a [[Labor Party of Israel|Labor]] member of the Knesset (MK), said that "all we can do is express our" support for Mubarak and hope the riots pass quietly.<ref>{{cite news |author=[[Staff writer]]|title=Ben-Eliezer: All We Can Do Is Express Support for Mubarak |url=http://www.jpost.com/Headlines/Article.aspx?id=205362 |work=[[The Jerusalem Post]] |date=26 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> He said Mubarak "had very tough things to say about the United States. [Mubarak] gave me a lesson in democracy and said: 'We see the democracy the United States spearheaded in Iran and with Hamas, in Gaza, and that's the fate of the Middle East. They may be talking about democracy but they don't know what they're talking about and the result will be extremism and radical Islam.'" According to him Mubarak realised "it was the end of the Mubarak era."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/11/us-egypt-israel-mubarak-idUSTRE71A64V20110211 |title=Mubarak slammed U.S. in phone call with Israeli lawmaker |publisher=Reuters |date=9 February 2009 |accessdate=13 February 2011}}</ref>
** [[Binyamin Ben-Eliezer]], a [[Labor Party of Israel|Labor]] member of the Knesset (MK), said that "all we can do is express our" support for Mubarak and hope the riots pass quietly.<ref>{{cite news |author=[[Staff writer]]|title=Ben-Eliezer: All We Can Do Is Express Support for Mubarak |url=http://www.jpost.com/Headlines/Article.aspx?id=205362 |work=[[The Jerusalem Post]] |date=26 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> He said Mubarak "had very tough things to say about the United States. [Mubarak] gave me a lesson in democracy and said: 'We see the democracy the United States spearheaded in Iran and with Hamas, in Gaza, and that's the fate of the Middle East. They may be talking about democracy but they don't know what they're talking about and the result will be extremism and radical Islam.'" According to him Mubarak realised "it was the end of the Mubarak era."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/11/us-egypt-israel-mubarak-idUSTRE71A64V20110211 |title=Mubarak slammed U.S. in phone call with Israeli lawmaker |publisher=Reuters |date=9 February 2009 |accessdate=13 February 2011}}</ref>
** MK [[Ibrahim Sarsur]], who leads the [[United Arab List]], expressed "full support for the protesters in Egypt. The Arab [[police state]]s have given their peoples no other option but to take to the streets for a peopleâs revolution to topple the suppressing regimes and to free themselves from the control of dictators."<ref>{{cite news |author=Gedalyahu, Tzvi Ben|title=Israeli Arab MK Joins Iran and Jordan Islamists To Back Protests|url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/142014|work=[[Arutz Sheva]]|date=30 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref>
** MK [[Ibrahim Sarsur]], who leads the [[United Arab List]], expressed "full support for the protesters in Egypt. The Arab [[police state]]s have given their peoples no other option but to take to the streets for a peopleâs revolution to topple the suppressing regimes and to free themselves from the control of dictators."<ref>{{cite news |author=Gedalyahu, Tzvi Ben|title=Israeli Arab MK Joins Iran and Jordan Islamists To Back Protests|url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/142014|work=[[Arutz Sheva]]|date=30 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref>

}}</ref> The arrest of two Brazilian journalists in Cairo on 2 February prompted the Ministry of External Relations to raise its tone in remarks about the political crisis in Egypt.<ref>http://www.estadao.com.br/noticias/internacional,apos-prisao-de-jornalistas-no-egito-itamaraty-eleva-tom,674951,0.htm</ref> it "deplore[d] the violent clashes [and] denounce[d] the arrests of Brazilian journalists Corban Costa, from [[RÃ¡dio Nacional]], and Gilvan Rocha, from [[TV Brasil]], and expects that Egyptian authorities take the appropriate measures to uphold the civil liberties and to protect the population at large and the foreigners on the ground from bodily harm."<ref>[[Press release]] (3 February 2011). [http://www.itamaraty.gov.br/sala-de-imprensa/notas-a-imprensa/situacao-no-egito-1 "Situation in Egypt"]. [[Ministry of External Relations (Brazil)|Brazilian Ministry of External Relations]]. }}</ref> The arrest of two Brazilian journalists in Cairo on 2 February prompted the Ministry of External Relations to raise its tone in remarks about the political crisis in Egypt.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.estadao.com.br/noticias/internacional,apos-prisao-de-jornalistas-no-egito-itamaraty-eleva-tom,674951,0.htm |title=ApÃ³s prisÃ£o de jornalistas no Egito, Itamaraty eleva tom ("After the Arrest of Journalists in Egypt, Foreign Ministry Raises Tone") (in [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]]) |publisher=Estadao.com.br |date= |accessdate=2011-04-27}}</ref> it "deplore[d] the violent clashes [and] denounce[d] the arrests of Brazilian journalists Corban Costa, from [[RÃ¡dio Nacional]], and Gilvan Rocha, from [[TV Brasil]], and expects that Egyptian authorities take the appropriate measures to uphold the civil liberties and to protect the population at large and the foreigners on the ground from bodily harm."<ref>[[Press release]] (3 February 2011). [http://www.itamaraty.gov.br/sala-de-imprensa/notas-a-imprensa/situacao-no-egito-1 "Situation in Egypt"]. [[Ministry of External Relations (Brazil)|Brazilian Ministry of External Relations]]. Retrieved 3 February 2011.</ref>
[[File:Obama calls Mubarak Oval Office Jan 2011.jpg|thumb|U.S. President [[Barack Obama]] speaks on the phone with Mubarak during the protests]]
[[File:Obama calls Mubarak Oval Office Jan 2011.jpg|thumb|U.S. President [[Barack Obama]] speaks on the phone with Mubarak during the protests]]
{{quote box|width=216px|quote="Violence will not address the grievances of the Egyptian people, and suppressing ideas never succeeds in making them go away.... Around the world governments have an obligation to respond to their citizens.... All governments must maintain power through consent, not coercion. That is the single standard by which the people of Egypt will achieve the future they deserve."|source=â Barack Obama<ref>{{cite web|author=Werner, Erica|url=http://wokv.com/common/ap/2011/01/29/D9L1UHTG0.html |title=Obama Admonishes Egypt's Mubarak on Protests |publisher=''[[Associated Press]]'' (via ''[[WOKV]]'') |date=undated (copyright 2011) |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5hJYBPPuG4Y1vq7XMe3NnsL7yOqRQ?docId=e5469a82800b40e498667d555837548f |title=Obama Calls for Restraint, Reform in Egypt |publisher=''[[Associated Press]]'' (via ''[[Google News]]'') |date=30 January 2011 |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref><ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|url=http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/index.php?pid=88942&st=&st1=|title=Remarks on the Situation in Egypt|publisher=John T. Woolley and Gerhard Peters, The American Presidency Project [online]|date=28 January 2011|accessdate= 29 January 2011}}</ref>}}

Line 181: Line 181:
In [[South Africa]], on 4 February, approximately 300 demonstrators blocked Bourke Street, the location of the Egyptian embassy in [[Pretoria]],<ref>[[Department of International Relations and Cooperation]] (South Africa). [http://www.dfa.gov.za/foreign/forrep/fore.htm#egy "Foreign Representatives in South Africa"]. Retrieved 10 February 2011.</ref> in peaceful protests organised by South African trade unions, human rights groups, and Egyptians in South Africa. The demonstrators shouted slogans such as "out with Mubarak" in English, [[Afrikaans]], [[Zulu language|Zulu]], and [[Arabic language|Arabic]].<ref>Associated Press (4 February 2011). [http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/02/04/AR2011020402335.html "S. Africans rally to support Egypt protesters"]. ''[[Washington Post]]''. Retrieved 10 February 2011.</ref>
In [[South Africa]], on 4 February, approximately 300 demonstrators blocked Bourke Street, the location of the Egyptian embassy in [[Pretoria]],<ref>[[Department of International Relations and Cooperation]] (South Africa). [http://www.dfa.gov.za/foreign/forrep/fore.htm#egy "Foreign Representatives in South Africa"]. Retrieved 10 February 2011.</ref> in peaceful protests organised by South African trade unions, human rights groups, and Egyptians in South Africa. The demonstrators shouted slogans such as "out with Mubarak" in English, [[Afrikaans]], [[Zulu language|Zulu]], and [[Arabic language|Arabic]].<ref>Associated Press (4 February 2011). [http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/02/04/AR2011020402335.html "S. Africans rally to support Egypt protesters"]. ''[[Washington Post]]''. Retrieved 10 February 2011.</ref>
â
On 9 February in [[Ukraine]], [[FEMEN]] activists organised a topless protest<ref>[http://femen.livejournal.com/136430.html FEMEN Livejournal, photos]</ref> in front of the Egyptian embassy in [[Kiev]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.allvoices.com/contributed-news/8144289-topless-femen-activist-supports-the-egyptian-revolution-at-the-egyptian-embassy-in-kiev-photos|title=Topless FEMEN activist Supports the Egyptian Revolution in kiev|date=9 February 2011|accessdate=9 February 2011}}</ref>
+
On 9 February in [[Ukraine]], [[FEMEN]] activists organised a topless protest<ref>[http://femen.livejournal.com/136430.html FEMEN Livejournal, photos]</ref> in front of the Egyptian embassy in [[Kiev]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.allvoices.com/contributed-news/8144289-topless-femen-activist-supports-the-egyptian-revolution-at-the-egyptian-embassy-in-kiev-photos|title=Topless FEMEN activist Supports the Egyptian Revolution in kiev|date=9 February 2011|accessdate=9 February 2011}}</ref>
